Interface ec.ezlib.prim.Sendable

public interface Sendable
extends Callable
Objects that handle EZ message delivery requests themselves. Represents a resolvable reference hopefully eventually designating some object.

ignore()
For ignoring errors on purpose.
optProblem()
Use E.optProblem(obj) rather than obj.optProblem().
resolution()
Use E.resolution(obj) rather than obj.resolution().
sendAll(String, Object[])
sendAll() queues the message for delivery to the object (if any) designated by this Sendable.
sendAllOnly(String, Object[])
Like sendAll(), but no one cares about the outcome, so don't bother returning a reference that represents it.
state()
Use E.state(obj) rather than obj.state().

state 
 public abstract String state()
Use E.state(obj) rather than obj.state(). Sendable.state() is public only because Sendable is an interface.

See Also:
state
resolution 
 public abstract Object resolution()
Use E.resolution(obj) rather than obj.resolution(). Sendable.resolution() is public only because Sendable is an interface.

See Also:
resolution
optProblem 
 public abstract Throwable optProblem()
Use E.optProblem(obj) rather than obj.optProblem(). Sendable.optProblem() is public only because Sendable is an interface.

See Also:
optProblem
sendAll 
 public abstract Object sendAll(String verb,
                                Object args[])
sendAll() queues the message for delivery to the object (if any) designated by this Sendable. If a DEFERRED Sendable does not yet designate an object (as in an un-forwarded Promise), then the messages merely waits, forever if need be, until it does. If the returned reference comes to designate an object (as can be determined with "E.send(result, "ping", pongNoticer);"), then that object was the result of delivering the message, and therefore, the delivery was successful. A successful delivery implies successful delivery of all earlier messages sent on the same reference.

If a failure to delivery happens, or a communications failure prevents knowledge of whether a successful delivery happened, or this reference gets manually smashed (as can happen if it's a Promise), then this reference will become BROKEN, and the returned reference will be BROKEN as well, with an E system exception (yet to be defined) that explains what kind of problem happened. If the message is successfully delivered but terminates with a thrown exception, this will break the returned reference, but not the original reference.

See Also:
state, ping
sendAllOnly 
 public abstract void sendAllOnly(String verb,
                                  Object args[])
Like sendAll(), but no one cares about the outcome, so don't bother returning a reference that represents it. An adequate (though possibly inneficient) implementation of sendAllOnly() merely calls sendAll() and ignores the return result.

ignore 
 public abstract void ignore()
For ignoring errors on purpose. Currently does nothing. Eventually, we expect to be able to trace all broken references that get finalized without their errors either being examined or ignore()d.
